<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
```c
int metal_generic_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;

	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W) {
			metal_cache_flush(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
		}
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
	}

	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
...
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_W 2
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Review of each parameter:
- bus, device: only cast to void, not written.
- dir: only read in a comparison (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W), not assigned or modified.
- nents_in: only read for the memcpy size and loop bound, not assigned or modified.
- sg_in, sg_out: the pointer variables themselves are not reassigned or incremented anywhere (no statements like sg_out = ..., sg_in++, etc.). The code writes to the objects pointed to by sg_out via memcpy and calls cache operations on memory referred to by sg_out[i].virt; modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by Rule 17.8, only modification of the pointer parameter itself would violate the rule.

Therefore there are no code fragments that modify function parameters themselves and thus nothing to report for investigation under Rule 17.8.
